title: 105_s2103
content: The "Personal Privacy Protection Act" is the short title of this legislation. It includes findings and purposes related to personal privacy. The "Personal Privacy Protection Act" includes findings that individuals and their families have been harassed and endangered by photographers, videographers, and audio recorders capturing images of their private lives for commercial purposes, violating their privacy interests. Federal legislation is needed to protect individuals and their families from harassment and trespass by using invasive devices for commercial purposes, as existing laws do not adequately cover such activities. Federal legislation is necessary to prohibit and provide redress in Federal courts for trespass and invasion of privacy using intrusive visual or auditory enhancement devices for commercial purposes. The first amendment does not protect persistent following or chasing that creates fear of bodily harm or trespassing with such devices. This Act aims to protect individuals from dangerous and intrusive activities by prohibiting specific actions without infringing on constitutional rights or other laws. It safeguards against harassment, endangerment, invasion of privacy, and trespass in a narrowly tailored manner. Congress has the power to enact this Act under the Constitution. The Act regulates conduct related to products for interstate or foreign commerce. Photos and activities regulated by the Act are routinely broadcast in interstate and international commerce. Photographers, videographers, and audio recorders travel in interstate commerce to engage in regulated activities for gaining material bought and sold in interstate commerce. The activities regulated by this Act occur routinely in channels of interstate commerce, such as following subjects inappropriately on public streets and using public areas for commercial purposes. The Act regulates activities that substantially affect interstate commerce by threatening the careers and rights of professional public persons in the media and restricting the movement of targeted individuals and their families. This can lead to limitations on travel or appearances in public spaces, forcing some to travel interstate to escape abuses. The Act aims to protect individuals and their families from bodily harm, privacy intrusions, and other threats related to activities in interstate and international commerce. It also seeks to safeguard interstate commerce affected by such activities and grants the right to injured parties to seek appropriate relief. SEC. 3. CRIMINAL OFFENSE. Chapter 89 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new section on harassment for commercial purposes. The term 'for commercial purposes' is defined as with the expectation of sale, financial gain, or other consideration. A visual image, sound recording, or physical impression is considered captured for commercial purposes if it was intended to be sold, published, or transmitted in interstate or foreign commerce. The new section on harassment for commercial purposes in Chapter 89 of title 18, United States Code, defines 'harasses' as persistently following or chasing a person to capture their image or recording for commercial gain. Penalties include imprisonment and fines for causing death or serious bodily injury through such harassment. In addition, individuals subjected to a violation of this section may seek relief through civil action, including compensatory damages, punitive damages, and attorney's fees. It states that only a person physically present and involved in a violation is subject to criminal charge or civil liability. PERSONAL INTRUSION FOR COMMERCIAL PURPOSES. The new section on harassment for commercial purposes in Chapter 89 of title 18, United States Code, includes limitations on defenses and the use of images. Only a person physically present and involved in a violation is subject to criminal charge or civil liability. The prohibitions of this section do not apply to official law enforcement activities. Nothing in this section preempts any right or remedy available under Federal, State, or local law. The term 'for commercial purposes' is defined as involving sale, financial gain, or other consideration. A visual image, sound recording, or physical impression is considered captured for commercial purposes if it is sold, published, or transmitted in commerce. Trespass for commercial purposes is deemed unlawful. It is illegal to trespass on private property to capture images or recordings of individuals for commercial gain. Similarly, capturing personal or familial activities for commercial use without consent, even without physical trespass, is also prohibited if there is a reasonable expectation of privacy. The section prohibits capturing images or recordings through trespass or use of enhancement devices without consent. Legal action can be taken by individuals subjected to violations, with the possibility of obtaining compensatory and punitive damages. Attorney's fees, including expert fees, may be awarded to the prevailing party in civil actions. The section prohibits capturing images or recordings without consent. It is not a defense to claim that no image was captured or sold. Use of images must be lawful. Only individuals physically present and involved in the violation are liable, not their agents or employees. The section prohibits capturing images or recordings without consent, with exemptions for law enforcement activities. It does not preempt any rights or remedies available under other laws. SEC. 5. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act or its amendments is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act and its provisions will not be affected.
